title: BNY Mellon’s Scharf named CEO of embattled Wells Fargo
text:
Wells Fargo announced Friday that it has chosen Bank of New York Mellon CEO Charles Scharf as its next chief executive, as the embattled firm works to rebuild its reputation.

Scharf will begin running the fourth-largest U.S. bank effective Oct. 21, nearly seven months after the departure of CEO Tim Sloan — the second chief executive to step down from Wells since late 2016, when it was revealed that the bank had opened potentially millions of accounts without customers’ permission.

In the weeks leading up to Sloan’s resignation, regulators criticized the giant bank for not making enough progress in overhauling itself after a raft of abuses that have steadily come to light, including charging hundreds of thousands of people for auto insurance they didn’t need. He also faced intense criticism from Congress.

The Federal Reserve has forbidden the bank from growing any larger until it improves its ability to manage and communicate risks across the entire company, and interim CEO Allen Parker earlier this year declined to speculate how soon that could be accomplished. “We have a substantial amount of work yet to do,” he said in April.

Scharf — who will run the San Francisco-based lender from New York — was already leading one of the largest banks in the country. Bank of New York Mellon safeguards trillions of dollars in assets for companies, pension funds and other institutions. Prior to his job at the custody bank, he served as CEO of Visa and has also previously worked at JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup — two of the other largest banks in the country.

“I am honored and energized by the opportunity to assume leadership of this great institution, which is important to our financial system and in the midst of fundamental change,” Scharf said in a statement. “I have deep respect for all the work that has taken place to transform Wells Fargo, and I look forward to working closely with the board, members of the management team, and team members.”

“I am committed to fully engaging with all of our stakeholders including regulators, customers, elected officials, investors, and communities,” he added.

One of Wells’ regulators, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, had the authority to block the hiring, if had chosen to do so, under the terms of an enforcement action against the bank.

“While the OCC does not comment on specific supervisory matters pertaining to particular institutions, the bank sought, and the OCC provided, written determination of no supervisory objection prior to the bank’s announcement,” OCC spokesperson Bryan Hubbard said in a statement.

Bank of New York Mellon Chief Financial Officer Todd Gibbons will take over as interim CEO at that firm, the bank said in a press release.
